items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message: River levels remain high at the Sandhurst river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. The tides are now below Flood Alert Threshold. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Mythe peaked at, 3.99m on 14/12/23, Haw Bridge, peaked at 5.1m on 14/12/23. No other gauges are impacted. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock and Kegworth river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this evening 18/12/23 and into tomorrow 19/12/23. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and low-lying agricultural land and roads around Cotes, Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar, Meadow Lane at Loughborough and the access road from Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. 
Whilst no significant rainfall is forecast over the next couple of days, the lake levels will remain high.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Churn. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. Levels are expected to continue falling today, but may rise again in response to rainfall overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. River levels remain high around Thrupp, but are forecast to continue gradually falling today. Levels are expected to begin rising tomorrow in response to rainfall overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into Tuesday. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Actual peak:- Llanymynech 4.22m Monday morning, 11/12/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, we expect river levels to remain high and potentially rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 19/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high around Malton and Low Marishes due to recent persistent rainfall, but continue to fall slowly. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are continuing to fall below levels of concern.
We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but gradually falling on the River Evenlode and River Glyme. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Woodstock area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. River levels have fallen on the River Evenlode, but levels remain high and are slowly falling on the River Glyme near Woodstock. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today, but will rise again in response to rainfall overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. We expect river levels to continue falling over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.message:

The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Osney and New Botley areas. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. We expect river levels to continue gradually falling over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Lower Dorset Frome but we have started to see levels falling in the last 48 hours. Levels at our Stinsford and East Stoke Gauges are falling slowly but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday. Rivers are likely to respond rapidly to any rainfall.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed. However, low lying fields in Currymoor will continue to be affected by flood water until pumping operations can clear this.

No property flooding is expected at this time.

The forecast for Monday is for patchy showers, before a band of heavier rain moves in overnight and into Tuesday morning. River levels still remain quite high, and Tuesday’s rain is expected to cause these to rise as water makes its way down through the system.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels within the rivers and moors, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

Continue to take care on roads and footpaths near rivers and flooded areas and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into Tuesday. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
The groundwater level at most of the monitoring boreholes across the Chase remains high, although several have fallen back very slightly over the weekend. A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 15mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and potentially rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 19/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are falling slowly but remain high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries due to the heavy rainfall in the last week and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but slowly falling. Flooding is still thought to be affecting land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, fields near Shripney Lane, and be close to properties on Durban Road, Bersted. In Barnham, river levels have now fallen nearer to normal and no flood impacts are presently expected. Monday (18/12/2023) will remain dry. The Aldingbourne Rife should continue to slowly fall today (Monday 18/12/2023). 10-20mm of rain is possible on Tuesday (19/12/2023), which could cause river levels to rise again. Minor flood impacts could be possible in Barnham. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 on 19/12/2023.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Monday 18th December and for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Water levels also remain high around Wayford Bridge and Hoveton Broad. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Tuesday 19th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message:
River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area.

Levels are expected to stay high for several days but are expected to fall slowly. On Roam Drain, levels are still rising slowly with the areas most at risk including low lying land around Hempholme. We are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00pm on Monday 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries due to the heavy rainfall in the last week and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

levels have peaked and are falling slowly. Levels are forecast to remain above the Flood Alert level for at least the next 3 days. Rain id forecast for Tuesday which may lead to levels raising once more.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 15mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday. Rivers are likely to respond rapidly to any rainfall.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and potentially rise again over the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 19/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently falling on the River Leach. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Lechlade area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. We expect river levels continue falling today, but levels may rise again in response to forecast rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks.
The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year but groundwater levels are currently declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are forecast to rise on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rainfall early tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.88m and falling slowly.

The pumping station drain level is 8.19m and falling steadily in response to pumping activities. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m. 

Monday is forecast to bring patchy showers across Somerset, before a heavier band of rain moves in overnight and on Tuesday morning. This is expected to clear by midday on Tuesday. Showers are forecast for the rest of the week.

We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.

Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by 1pm on Tuesday 19/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since Friday 08/12/2023, 41mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End, and the groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 2.63m. Groundwater is currently affecting the cellars of a small number of properties on Lower West and East Street. The football pitch is also being affected by a mixture of sewage and groundwater. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in the village are expected to continue rising until the middle of next week. It is likely that more properties will be affected by cellar flooding on West Street and East Street during this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 08/12/2023, 36mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton, and the groundwater level in Finchdean has risen by 26cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are now flowing. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties in Finchdean. Over the next 5 days, the weather is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in all villages are expected to rise for at least a week. In the next few days, it is possible that road flooding could begin to affect all villages, and cellar flooding could start to impact properties in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please remove valuables from cellars, and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: River Trent Tributaries in Nottinghamshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Trent, River Greet, Potwell Dyke, Carr Dyke, Dover Beck, Cocker Beck, Thurgarton Beck, Fairham Brook

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lowdham Grange river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from early hours in the morning, 19/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around the tributaries of the River Trent in Nottinghamshire, the River Greet, Potwell Dyke, Dover Beck, Cocker Beck, Woodborough Brook, Ouse Dyke, Thurgarton Beck and others.
Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Maun in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from approximately 07:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   
Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to begin rising early hours tomorrow morning on the, 19/12/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: River levels are gradually falling however remain high in the Blankney to Sleaford area. Further rainfall is forecast from Tuesday 19 December. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 19 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the Beverley and Barmston Drain and remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including around Beverley and Dunswell, and the central River Hull area including Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. No further significant rainfall is forecast, however river levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, as well as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Devon and Smite in Leicestershire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Colston Bassett river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads along the River Smite. Church Gate and Bunnison Lane in Colston Bassett could be impassable, with potentially dangerous depths of flood water.  Areas around the River Devon could also be affected at Easthorpe, Bottesford, Belvoir Lane and the Woolsthorpe to Belvoir road in Woolsthorpe, Church Lane and Main Street in Muston.
Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Soar catchment
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Sharnford, Littlethorpe and Freemans Weir river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this evening 18/12/23 and into tomorrow 19/12/23. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Sharnford, Croft, Littlethorpe, the Mill on the Soar car park and Falconry, Braunstone, Aylestone, Abbey Park, Birstall and Wanlip, and Braunstone Lane East.  
We expect river levels to begin rising from 21:00 on 18/12/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
Loughborough urban watercourses and local tributaries to the River Soar
items.message:

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this evening 18/12/23 and into tomorrow 19/12/23. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Kingfisher Way, Forest Road and Monarch Way from the Wood Brook, the Grace Dieu Brook, Burleigh Brook, Black Brook, Grammar School Brook, Hermitage Brook, Sileby Brook, Long Whatton Brook, King’s Brook and Kingston Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Low-lying land and farmlands in the Glenfield, Anstey, Thurcaston, Rothley, Newtown Linford, Cropston, Swithland and Quorn areas.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

items.message:

items.description: Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater
items.message: River levels are gradually falling however they remain high in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater area. Further rainfall is forecast Tuesday 19 December. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Frisby and Syston river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this evening 18/12/23 and into tomorrow 19/12/23. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Lower Derwent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of persistent  rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 18/12/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Weymouth Rivers and Streams
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan due to rising groundwater levels.

Levels at our Broadway gauge are starting to slowly fall but are likely to remain above the flood alert level for at least the next 2 days.

The forecast this evening and into Tuesday is for rain to return. River levels are likely to respond rapidly.

Flooding is possible at the River Wey to Radipole Lake, Preston Brook and River Jordan.

We are monitoring river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 16:00 on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Meden in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Church Warsop river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from early hours in the morning, 19/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads along the River Meden around Warsop, Church Warsop, Meden Vale and Budby.
Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Windrush. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Newbridge area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. River levels have fallen in the upper reaches. Levels remain high at Newbridge but will continue to slowly fall throughout today. Levels may rise again in the next couple of days in response to rainfall overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Kempsey Village
River Severn in Worcestershire
Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent persistent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. River levels are expected to remain high for several days and we are operating pumps in the area. We continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00pm on Monday 18/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on 18/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 39cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 60cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 19/12/23.

items.description: River Wye in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Ashford river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight, 18/12/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning on 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 at Chilgrove. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but then no rain to Sunday 24/12/2023. Groundwater at Chilgrove's borehole, is expected to continue falling, but with a temporary slowing Thursday and Friday. At the East Dean borehole, groundwater will stay at the surface. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels are gradually falling however remain high in the Heighington to Dunston area. Further rainfall is forecast Tuesday 19 December. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 19 December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Hooke
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have fallen away over the weekend and the risk of groundwater flooding has passed for the moment. A band of potentially heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area over the next 24 hours which may cause a slight rise, but this is not expected to cause levels to return to those experienced earlier in the month. More unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the month, however. We will continue to monitor the situation and this warning will be re-issued should levels rise again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at Kingston Russell borehole has fallen back very slightly over the weekend, however with up to 15mm of rainfall forecast over the next 24 hours a further, small upward rise is possible before things settle back down towards the latter part of the week. This may see a re-appearance of flood water on roads in Martinstown and the Winterbourne villages and possibly on the A354 west of Winterbourne Abbas, although the impact will be rather less than was experienced over the last two weeks.
Householders are advised to check property level resilience measures including, pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. Do not drive through flood water unless absolutely necessary as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties.
this message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cerne Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down and Doles Ash boreholes have fallen away over the weekend and the risk of groundwater flooding has passed for the moment. A band of potentially heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area over the next 24 hours which may cause a slight rise, but this is not expected to cause levels to return to those experienced earlier in the month. More unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the month, however. We will continue to monitor the situation and this warning will be re-issued should levels rise again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Sydling
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have fallen away over the weekend and the risk of groundwater flooding has passed for the moment. A band of potentially heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area over the next 24 hours which may cause a slight rise, but this is not expected to cause levels to return to those experienced earlier in the month. More unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the month, however. We will continue to monitor the situation and this warning will be re-issued should levels rise again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Devils Brook
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have fallen away over the weekend and the risk of groundwater flooding has passed for the moment. A band of potentially heavy rainfall is forecast to cross the area over the next 24 hours which may cause a slight rise, but this is not expected to cause levels to return to those experienced earlier in the month. More unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the month, however. We will continue to monitor the situation and this warning will be re-issued should levels rise again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Doles Ash borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly falling on the River Dikler. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Bourton On The Water area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling throughout today, but may rise again in response to rainfall overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have stabilised on the Ginge Brook, although the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Steventon area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. River levels are expected to slowly fall today, but may rise again in response to rainfall overnight.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface, but currently slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but with no rain Wednesday to Sunday 24/12/2023. Despite Tuesday's rain, groundwater is expected to continue to slowly fall through to next week. If  groundwater rises following Tuesday's rain, it should peak by Sunday 24/12/2023, not significantly higher than recent heights. Groundwater will remain higher than normal, sensitive to any additional rainfall, with risk of flood over the winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but falling on the lower River Kennet. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Theale area. Rain is forecast this afternoon, this will become widespread and heavier overnight into Tuesday. We expect river levels to continue gradually falling today, but levels are expected to rise again tomorrow in response to rainfall overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Ladies Mile borehole. 15mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 19/12/2023, but with no rain Wednesday to Sunday 24/12/2023. Despite the rain Tuesday, groundwater at Ladies Mile borehole is likely to continue falling through to the weekend. However, the rate of fall could slow. If the maximum predicted rainfall, or more, occurs, groundwater could possibly rise again, however groundwater flood impacts are not currently thought likely this week. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 21/12/2023

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. The forecast is for rain this evening and during Tuesday before turning more settled on Wednesday.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (322mm) was recorded in Andover. At Clanville Gate, the rate of rise is slow, at 10cm per day. We expect groundwater to be impacting the sewer network at Penton Mewsey and the main road at Penton Grafton is expected to be impacted by flooding within the next few days. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. It is possible that a very small number of cellars will be affected in Appleshaw from Friday 15/12/2023. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to become drier, however we expect levels to continue to rise for at least the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables stored in cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (381mm) was recorded at our rain gauge in Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has increased by 19cm. At the current rate of rise, cellar flooding is possible from Thursday 14/12/2023 at the southern end of the village at South End Close. From Saturday 16/12/2023, cellar flooding could occur at the Dolphin Inn Pub and impacts to the sewage network could be experienced. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to be drier, however levels are still expected to rise for at least another week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated at 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into Tuesday. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation change

items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, south of the A354
items.message:
Groundwater levels at the Delcombe Wood borehole have settled back a little over the weekend, but remain very high for the time of year. Up to 15mm of rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and this may well trigger a small increase in level. This may lead to flooding of roads and cellars. After a brief drier spell a return to more unsettled weather is forecast for the remainder of the month.
Householders should check that any property level resilience measures they have in place such as pumps, flood barriers or air brick covers are still working effectively. Motorists are advised to avoid driving through flood water wherever possible as the bow wave from vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. 
This message will be updated on Wednesday 20th December or as the situation change

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (451mm) was recorded in Warnford. The winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for several weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. At our borehole at Pound Lane, the groundwater level will stabilise by Friday 15/12/2023, before beginning to slowly fall. Long range forecasting is difficult, but there is currently an indication that unsettled weather will return to Hampshire from the end of next week. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will rise again, and water will begin flowing across Rectory Lane. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding south of the Humber Estuary
items.message: The risk of flooding from groundwater south of the Humber Estuary has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
The groundwater level at most of the monitoring boreholes across Salisbury Plain continue to rise quite slowly. On the West Wiltshire downs including the Wylye Valley and the Vale of Wardour, levels have settled back a bit over the weekend. 
 A frontal system will pass over the area during Tuesday morning, bringing up to 10mm of rain on higher ground, and due to the saturated nature of the catchment, expect groundwater levels to respond quite quickly. Following a brief dry period through the middle of the week, a return to more unsettled weather will return from Saturday. Homeowners are advised to check any property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Wednesday the 20th December or as the situation changes.
